Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution over a rod of length L is governed by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. The transformation considered is applying a Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) to the initial temperature distribution \\(u(x,0)\\).

If at a certain time \\(t_1\\), a new transformation \\(\\mathcal{F}^{-1}\\) (inverse Fourier transform) is applied as an intervention, will the final temperature distribution \\(u(x,T)\\) for T > t_1 depend only on the heat equation and not on the initial or intermediate transformations?
Explanation: The final temperature distribution \\(u(x,T)\\) will depend on the sequence and type of transformations applied (both \\(\\mathcal{F}\\) and \\(\\mathcal{F}^{-1}\\)), as well as the heat diffusion governed by the equation. These transformations influence the modal distribution and interactions, significantly affecting the outcome.
